1. Kenny Williams is the tallest.

Next, Chris Jackson is 6'0", which is indeed the shortest listed here, so that part of the claim is correct.

Now checking if both were selected in the NBA draft. The "nba draft" column shows:

- Alonzo Mourning: 1st round - 2nd pick (Hornets) in 1992.
- Chris Jackson: 1st round - 3rd pick (Nuggets) in 1990.
- Chris Mills: 1st round - 22nd pick (Cavs) in 1993.
- Billy Owens: 1st round - 3rd pick (Kings) in 1991.
- Kenny Williams: 2nd round - 46th pick (Pacers) in 1990.

Both Kenny and Chris Jackson were drafted, so the NBA selection part is correct. However, since Kenny isn't the only tallest player, but shares that height with Alonzo Mourning, the claim about him being "the tallest" is not fully accurate because there's another player of the same height.

Therefore, the entire claim isn't completely true because while both were selected to play in the NBA and Chris Jackson is indeed the shortest, Kenny Williams isn't uniquely the tallest; he shares that distinction with Alonzo Mourning.

2. Chris Jackson: Drafted in the 1st round, 3rd pick of the 1990 draft by the Nuggets. He attended LSU, so again, likely drafted during his eligibility.

3. Chris Mills: Selected in the 1st round, 22nd pick of the 1993 draft by the Cavaliers. His college was Kentucky/Arizona, which aligns with typical draft timelines, suggesting he was drafted when eligible.

4. Billy Owens: Drafted in the 1st round, 3rd pick of the 1991 draft by the Kings. Syracuse players often enter the NBA after their college years, so this fits.

5. Kenny Williams: He was picked in the 2nd round, 46th pick of the 1990 draft by the Pacers. His colleges were Barton CC and Elizabeth City State, which are community colleges. However, usually, players from community colleges might take a bit longer to enter the NBA, but he did get drafted in 1990, which should be his eligible season.

Now, considering whether all five were selected during their eligibility years, I don't see any red flags. Each player's draft year seems to align with when they would have been eligible based on their college attendance. There's no indication that any of them waited beyond their eligible seasons to get drafted.

Therefore, the claim appears to be supported by the data in the table.
</think>

The claim is TRUE because all five players were selected during the NBA draft in the season they were eligible, as indicated by their respective draft years matching when they would have been eligible based on their college attendance.
